title: Dimension properties of the boundaries of exponential basins

title_detail.value: Dimension properties of the boundaries of exponential basins

summary:
We prove that the boundary of a component $U$ of the basin of an attracting
periodic cycle (of period greater than 1) for an exponential map on the complex
plane has Hausdorff dimension greater than 1 and less than 2. Moreover, the set
of points in the boundary of $U$ which do not escape to infinity has Hausdorff
dimension (in fact: hyperbolic dimension) greater than 1, while the set of
points in the boundary of $U$ which escape to infinity has Hausdorff dimension
1.

summary_detail.value:
We prove that the boundary of a component $U$ of the basin of an attracting
periodic cycle (of period greater than 1) for an exponential map on the complex
plane has Hausdorff dimension greater than 1 and less than 2. Moreover, the set
of points in the boundary of $U$ which do not escape to infinity has Hausdorff
dimension (in fact: hyperbolic dimension) greater than 1, while the set of
points in the boundary of $U$ which escape to infinity has Hausdorff dimension
1.

author: Anna Zdunik
fulltext:
DIMENSION PROPERTIES OF THE BOUNDARIES OF EXPONENTIAL BASINS arXiv:0902.1065v1 [math.DS] 6 Feb 2009 KRZYSZTOF BARAŃSKI, BOGUSLAWA KARPIŃSKA, AND ANNA ZDUNIK Abstract. We prove that the boundary of a component U of the basin of an attracting periodic cycle (of period greater than 1) for an exponential map on the complex plane has Hausdorff dimension greater than 1 and less than 2. Moreover, the set of points in the boundary of U which do not escape to infinity has Hausdorff dimension (in fact: hyperbolic dimension) greater than 1, while the set of points in the boundary of U which escape to infinity has Hausdorff dimension 1. 1. Introduction Let f (z) = λ exp(z) for λ ∈ C \ {0}, z ∈ C be an exponential map with an attracting periodic cycle of period p. Then the Julia set J(f ) is equal to the boundary of the (entire) basin B of attraction to this cycle. We are interested in dimension properties of this boundary. We consider also the escaping set I(f ) = {z ∈ C : f n (z) → ∞ as n → ∞} and the set of points in the Julia set with bounded forward trajectories Jbd (f ) = {z ∈ J(f ) : {f n (z)}∞ n=0 is bounded}. In our context, both set are contained in the boundary of B. In the well-known case p = 1, the attracting basin consists of a unique simply connected component U. As proved in [11], the Hausdorff dimension dimH of its boundary ∂U = J(f ) is then equal to 2. In fact, it follows from the proof in [11] that dimH (∂U) = dimH (∂U ∩ I(f )) = 2. On the other hand, we have 1 < dimH (∂U ∩ Jbd (f )) ≤ dimH (∂U \ I(f )) < 2 (see [8, 15]). A refined analysis of the dimension of subsets of I(f ) according to the speed of convergence to ∞ can be found in [10]. Hence, it follows from the above results that in the case p = 1 the dimension of ∂U is carried by the set of escaping points. Consider now the case p > 1. Then the basin B of the attracting cycle consists of infinitely many disjoint simply connected components. Again, the Hausdorff dimension of the boundary of B is equal to 2 (see [11]). However, this does not imply that the Date: February 6, 2009. 2000 Mathematics Subject Classification. Primary 37F10, 37F35, 30D40, 28A80. Research supported by Polish MNiSW Grant N N201 0234 33 and EU FP6 Marie Curie Programmes RTN CODY and ToK SPADE2. The second author is supported by Polish PW Grant 504G 1120 0011 000. 1 2 KRZYSZTOF BARAŃSKI, BOGUSLAWA KARPIŃSKA, AND ANNA ZDUNIK boundaries of components of B have Hausdorff dimension 2. In fact, in this paper we prove the following theorem. Theorem A. Let p > 1 and let U be a component of the basin of the attracting cycle for the map f . Then the boundary of U has Hausdorff dimension greater than 1 and less than 2. This shows that for p > 1 the dimension of ∂U is carried by points in the Julia set, which are not in the boundary of any component of the Fatou set (so-called buried points). By Theorem A, we immediately obtain: Corollary A'. If p > 1, then the set of buried points for the map f has Hausdorff dimension 2. Surprisingly, for p > 1 the role of escaping and non-escaping points in ∂U from dimensional point of view is quite different than in the case p = 1. This is shown in the second result proved in this paper. Theorem B. If p > 1 and U is a component of the basin of the attracting cycle for the map f , then while 1 < dimH (∂U ∩ Jbd (f )) ≤ dimH (∂U \ I(f )) = dimH (∂U) < 2, dimH (∂U ∩ I(f )) = 1. Remark. In fact, the proof of Theorem B shows that ∂U ∩Jbd (f ) has hyperbolic dimension greater than 1. Therefore, in the case p > 1 the dimension of ∂U is carried by the set of non-escaping points. Remark. It is easy to check that for z ∈ ∂U we have f n (z) −−−→ ∞ ⇐⇒ f np (z) −−−→ ∞ n→∞ n→∞ (see Lemma 7). Recall that J(f ) consists of so-called hairs homeomorphic to [0, ∞), tending to ∞, composed of points with given symbolic itineraries. All points from a hair outside its endpoint (the point corresponding to 0 in [0, ∞)) are contained in I(f ). In the case p = 1 the hairs are pairwise disjoint and the Julia set is homeomorphic to a so-called straight brush (see [1]), while in the case p > 1 some hairs have common endpoints and the Julia set is a modified straight brush (see [5]). In both cases the Hausdorff dimension of the union of hairs without endpoints is equal to 1 (see [9, 13]). Hence, the hairs without endpoints are insignificant from dimensional point of view. The plan of the paper is as follows. In Section 2 we describe combinatorics of exponential maps with a periodic basin of attraction and provide a symbolic description of the boundaries of its components (Proposition 3). Then, in Section 3 we prove that the set of escaping points in the boundary U has Hausdorff dimension 1. In Section 4 it is shown that DIMENSION PROPERTIES OF THE BOUNDARIES OF EXPONENTIAL BASINS 3 the set of points in the boundary of U with bounded trajectories has hyperbolic dimension greater than 1. Finally, Section 5 concludes the proof. 2. Combinatorics of exponentials with attracting periodic basins The combinatorics of the Julia sets of exponential maps with an attracting periodic cycle of period p > 1 was described in [4, 5]. For completeness, we briefly recall the construction from these papers. Let z0 , . . . , zp = z0 be the attracting cycle and let U0 , . . . , Up = U0 be the components of the basin of attraction, such that zj ∈ Uj . Of course, we have f p (Uj ) ⊂ Uj . All Uj are simply connected (see e.g. [2]). Since 0 is the only singular value of f , it must be in a component containing some zj , so we can assume 0 ∈ U1 . It is easy to find a simply connected domain Bp+1 ⊂ U1 such that 0, z1 ∈ Bp+1 , ∂Bp+1 is a Jordan curve in U1 and f p (Bp+1 ) ⊂ Bp+1 . Let Bp = f −1 (Bp+1 ). Then Bp is simply connected, contains some left-half plane and ∂Bp is a curve homeomorphic to the real line, contained in {z ∈ C : a < Re(z) < b} for some a, b ∈ R. This curve is periodic of period 2πi and its two "ends" have imaginary parts tending respectively to ±∞. For j = p − 1, . . . , 0 define successively Bj to be the component of f −1 (Bj+1 ) containing zj . The construction implies that f maps univalently Bj onto Bj+1 for j = 1, . . . , p − 1, such that B1 ⊃ Bp+1 , and f on B0 = f −1 (B1 ) is a universal covering of B1 \ {0}. Let Cp ⊂ Bp be a domain containing z0 and some left half-plane {z : Re(z) < c}, such that ∂Cp is a curve homeomorphic to the real line, its two "ends" have imaginary parts tending to ±∞, moreover ∂Cp coincides with ∂Bp on {z : |Im(z)| < L1 } and is vertical on {z : |Im(z)| > L2 } for some large constants L1 , L2 > 0. Define successively Cj ⊂ Bj to be the component of f −1 (Cj+1) containing zj for j = p − 1, . . . , 0. Again, f maps univalently Cj onto Cj+1 and f on C0 = f −1 (C1 ) is a universal covering of C1 \ {0}. Moreover, since Bp+1 is compact, we have Bp+1 ⊂ C1 if the constant L1 is chosen sufficiently large. This implies Cj ⊂ Uj for j = 0, . . . , p − 1 and Cp ⊂ C0 . In particular, C0 , . . . , Cp−1 are pairwise disjoint. Since C0 contains some left half-plane and 0 ∈ / C0 , the set C \ C0 consists of infinitely many disjoint simply connected, closed, connected sets Hs , s ∈ Z, such that (1) Hs = H0 + 2πis Similarly, for j = 1, . . . , p − 1 the set C j is a simply connected, closed, connected subset of S s Hs , such that (2) zj ∈ Cj ⊂ Uj ⊂ Hkj for j = 1, . . . p − 1, for some kj ∈ Z. See Figure 1. The following lemma is essentially stated as Proposition 2.10 in [4]. 4 KRZYSZTOF BARAŃSKI, BOGUSLAWA KARPIŃSKA, AND ANNA ZDUNIK H mp −1 f Cp−1 zp −1 f H m2 C2 f z2 C0 Cp H m1 z0 C1 f z1 f 0 Figure 1. The sets Cj . Lemma 1. For s ∈ Z, j = 1, . . . , p−1, we have ∂Hs = Γs , ∂Cj = γj , where Γs , γj : R → C are curves homeomorphic to the real line, such that Re(Γs (t)), Re(γj (t)) −−−−→ +∞. t→±∞ Moreover, for sufficiently large M > 0, in the right half-plane {z : Re(z) ≥ M} the curves Γs , γj form pairs of the graphs of smooth functions y = Hs± (x), y = h± j (x), x ≥ M, where (x, y) are Euclidean coordinates on the plane and lim Hs± (x) = (2s + 1 ± 1)π − Arg(λ), x→+∞ lim h± p−1 (x) = (2kp−1 + 1 ± 1/2)π − Arg(λ), x→+∞ lim h± j (x) = 2πkj − Arg(λ) for j = 1, . . . , p − 2 x→+∞ for some branch of argument. Consequently, Hs ∩ {z : Re(z) ≥ M} ⊂ {z : (2s − 1)π − Arg(λ) < Im(z) < (2s + 3)π − Arg(λ)}. Proof. By construction, γp−1 ∩ {z : Re(z) ≥ M} for large M is a pair of curves, which are images of vertical half-lines under some branch of logarithm. Hence, these curves are the ± graphs of some smooth functions h± p−1 (x), such that limx→+∞ hp−1 (x) = (2kp−1 +1±1/2)π− DIMENSION PROPERTIES OF THE BOUNDARIES OF EXPONENTIAL BASINS 5 ′ Arg(λ) and |(h± p−1 ) | < ε for a small ε > 0. Moreover, the curves γj , j = p − 2, . . . , 1 and Γs are successive images of γp−1 under inverse branches of f , which have the form log(z/λ) for some branch of logarithm. Note also that | Arg(z)|, | Arg(log′ (z/λ))| < ε for every S z ∈ p−1 j=1 γj , provided Re(z) ≥ M for large M. This easily implies that γj and Γs on some right-half plane are pairs of smooth curves with almost horizontal tangent vector and the required asymptotics.  Since C \ C1 is simply connected and does not contain 0, we can define branches of f −1 , gs : C \ C1 → Hs , mapping C \ C1 onto Hs . Let L=C\ By construction, we have L ⊂ f (L), so p [ s ∈ Z, Cj j=1 gs (L) ⊂ L. Hence, the collection of maps {gs |L }s∈Z forms an infinite conformal iterated function system. Since the Julia set is the complement of the S basin of attraction, for each z ∈ J(f ) all its forward iterates are contained in L \ C0 ⊂ s Hs , so following [4], we can define its itinerary (s0 , s1 , . . .), taking sn ∈ Z such that f n (z) ∈ Hsn , n = 0, 1, . . .. It is clear that J(f ) = ∞ \ [ n=0 s0 ,...,sn gs0 ◦ * * * ◦ gsn (L), T and ∞ n=0 gs0 ◦ * * * ◦ gsn (L) is precisely the set of points in the Julia set with itinerary (s0 , s1 , . . .). Let k = (k1 , . . . , kp−1 ) be the block of p − 1 symbols, where k1 , . . . , kp−1 are integers defined in (2). See Figure 1. The block k describes the trajectory of the singular value 0 and is called the kneading sequence for f (see [4]). We will write Gk = gk1 ◦ * * * ◦ gkp−1 , Gs,k = gs ◦ gk1 ◦ * * * ◦ gkp−1 , Gk,s = gk1 ◦ * * * ◦ gkp−1 ◦ gs for s ∈ Z. The following lemma is a kind of folklore (it follows from estimations of hyperbolic metric, see e.g. the proofs of Proposition 6.1 in [11] and Proposition 2.1 in [14]). Lemma 2. There exist c > 0, A > 1, such that for every n > 0, s0 , . . . , sn ∈ Z and z ∈ L, |(gs0 ◦ * * * ◦ gsn )′ (z)| < cA−n .  6 KRZYSZTOF BARAŃSKI, BOGUSLAWA KARPIŃSKA, AND ANNA ZDUNIK Now we show how the boundary of a component of the basin of attraction is described in terms of symbolic sequences. We do not give a precise symbolic characterisation of the boundary, but provide a necessary and a sufficient conditions, which is enough for our purposes. To fix notation, we consider the component U0 . Let Σk = {(s0 , k, s1 , k, . . .) : s0 , s1 , . . . ∈ Z}, / {k1 , . . . , kp−1 } for infinitely many n}. Σ′k = {(s0 , k, s1 , k, . . .) : s0 , s1 , . . . ∈ Z and sn ∈ Proposition 3. {z ∈ J(f ) : z has itinerary in Σ′k } ⊂ ∂U0 ⊂ {z ∈ J(f ) : z has itinerary in Σk }. Proof. First, we show ∂U0 ⊂ {z ∈ J(f ) : z has itinerary in Σk }. Take z ∈ ∂U0 and n ≥ 0. We need to check that f n (z) ∈ Hkj if n = lp + j for an integer l and j ∈ {1, . . . , p − 1}. It is clear that f lp+j (z) ∈ ∂Uj . Moreover, Uj must be contained in Hkj , since it is a connected S subset of s Hs containing zj ∈ Cj ⊂ Hkj . This shows f lp+j (z) ∈ Hkj . Now we show {z ∈ J(f ) : z has itinerary in Σ′k } ⊂ ∂U0 . Take a point z ∈ J(f ) with itinerary in Σ′k . By definition, there are arbitrarily large n such that f np (z) ∈ Hsn and sn 6= kj for j ∈ {1, . . . , p − 1}. This implies that for these n we have Hsn ⊂ L. Let In be a open vertical segment in Hsn containing f np (z), such that both endpoints of In are in ∂Hsn . Note that the length of In is less than 2π because of (1). Let Gn be the branch of f −np along the trajectory of z, i.e. Gn = Gs0 ,k ◦ * * * ◦ Gsn−1 ,k . Since In ⊂ Hsn ⊂ L, the branch Gn is defined on In . By Lemma 2, the length of Gn (In ) tends to 0 as n → ∞. Moreover, by the definition of the sets Cj , each map Gsl ,k maps points from U0 to points from U0 . Hence, the endpoints of the curve Gn (In ) are in U0 . Since z ∈ Gn (In ), this shows z ∈ ∂U0 .  3. Escaping points in the boundary In this section we prove: Proposition 4. The Hausdorff dimension of the set {z ∈ J(f ) : z has itinerary in Σk } ∩ I(f ) is equal to 1. In the proof of this proposition, it is more convenient to consider the set Σ̃k = {(k, s1 , k, s2 , . . .) : s1 , s2 , . . . ∈ Z} instead of Σk . Note that the set {z ∈ J(f ) : z has itinerary in Σk } ∩ I(f ) is a countable union of the images of {z ∈ J(f ) : z has itinerary in Σ̃k } ∩ I(f ) under inverse branches of f , so both sets have the same Hausdorff dimension. Hence, to prove Proposition 4, it is sufficient to show that (3) dimH ({z ∈ J(f ) : z has itinerary in Σ̃k } ∩ I(f )) = 1. DIMENSION PROPERTIES OF THE BOUNDARIES OF EXPONENTIAL BASINS 7 Let for a large integer M > 0 and WM = {z : Re(z) ≥ M} AM = {z ∈ J(f ) : z has itinerary in Σ̃k and f n (z) ∈ WM for all n ≥ 0}. The assertion (3) will follow immediately from Proposition 5. For every δ > 0 there exists M(δ) > 0 such that for every M > M(δ), dimH AM < 1 + δ. The rest of this section is devoted to the proof of Proposition 5. Definition. Let Qrs = L ∩ Hs ∩ {z : r ≤ Re(z) < r + 1} for r, s ∈ Z, r ≥ M and let Qr be the family of all connected components of Qrk1 . Remark 6. Note that if M is sufficiently large, then by Lemma 1, each family Qr consists of at most p sets. Let K0 = and for n ≥ 0 define inductively ∞ [ r=M Qr Kn+1 = {Gk,s (K) : K ∈ Kn , s ∈ Z and Gk,s (K) ∩ WM 6= ∅}. Note that if x ∈ AM , then for every n ≥ 0 we have f np (x) ∈ L ∩ Hk1 ∩ WM , so f np (x) belongs to some set K0 ∈ K0 . Since [ K0 , L ∩ Hk1 ∩ WM = K0 ∈K0 this implies that the collection Kn is a cover of AM . Fix δ > 0. We will show that (4) and sup{diam K : K ∈ Kn } → 0 as n → ∞. (5) X (diam K)1+δ < 1 K∈Kn for every n ≥ 0, which will prove Proposition 5 by the definition of the Hausdorff measure. To show (4) and (5), we first prove two simple lemmas. Lemma 7. For every sufficiently large M there exists M1 > 0, such that M1 → ∞ as M → ∞, and for every z ∈ L ∩ WM and s ∈ Z, for every j = 1, . . . , p − 1. f j (Gk,s (z)) ∈ WM1 8 KRZYSZTOF BARAŃSKI, BOGUSLAWA KARPIŃSKA, AND ANNA ZDUNIK Proof. It it sufficient to notice that Re(gs (z)) = ln |z| − ln |λ| ≥ ln(Re(z)) − ln |λ|.  Lemma 8. For every z ∈ L ∩ WM for sufficiently large M, |G′k,s (z)| < 1 . Re(z)(π|s| + 1) Proof. By the chain rule, |G′k,s (z)| = |gs′ (z)||gk′ p−1 (gs (z))||(gk1 ◦ * * * ◦ gkp−2 )′ (gkp−1 ◦ gs (z))|. We have |gs′ (z)| = 1/|z| ≤ 1/Re(z). Moreover, by Lemma 1, there exists a constant c > 0, such that |gk′ p−1 (gs (z))| = 1 2 2 1 ≤ < < |gs (z)| (|Re(gs (z))| + |Im(gs (z))|) ln M + 2π|s| − c π|s| + 1 for large M. Finally, by Lemma 7, ′ |(gk1 ◦ * * * ◦ gkp−2 ) (gkp−1 ◦ gs (z))| = p−2 Y j=1 1 |f j (G k,s (z))| ≤ p−2 Y j=1 1 Re(f j (G if M is sufficiently large. k,s (z))) < 1 ≤ 1, M1p−2  Note that by Lemma 1, for every K0 ∈ K0 we have (6) diam K0 < √ 1 + 16π 2 . Moreover, by Lemma 8, for every K ∈ Kn , diam Gk,s (K) < diam K , M − diam K which shows (4) by a simple induction. Moreover, (4) and Lemma 8 imply immediately the following fact. Corollary 9. For every K ∈ Kn and every z ∈ K, |G′k,s (z)| < for some constant d > 0. 1 (M − d)(π|s| + 1)  DIMENSION PROPERTIES OF THE BOUNDARIES OF EXPONENTIAL BASINS 9 Now we are ready to prove (5). Using Remark 6, Lemma 8 and Corollary 9 we get, for some constants c1 , c2 > 0, X X X (diam Gk,s1 ◦ * * * ◦ Gk,sn (K0 ))1+δ (diam K)1+δ = K0 ∈K0 K∈Kn ≤ ∞ X X r=M K0 ∈Qr s1 ,...,sn ∈Z: Gk,sj ◦***◦Gk,sn (K0 )∈Kn−j+1 for j=1,...,n X sup s1 ,...,sn ∈Z: Gk,sj ◦***◦Gk,sn (K0 )∈Kn−j+1 for j=1,...,n z∈K0 |G′k,sn (z)| n−1 Y j=1 |G′k,sj (Gk,sj+1 ◦ * * * ◦ Gk,sn (z))| !1+δ !1+δ n−1 Y 1 1

R/2 − D for some constant D > 0. Hence, by the Koebe Lemma (see e.g. [7]), the distortion of these branches on Q is bounded by a constant independent of R, u, s. Let Qu,s = Gu,k ◦ Gs,k (Q) for u, s ∈ Z and G = {(u, s) ∈ Z2 : Qu,s ⊂ Q}. 10 KRZYSZTOF BARAŃSKI, BOGUSLAWA KARPIŃSKA, AND ANNA ZDUNIK Now define X= ∞ \ [ n=1 i1 ,...,in hi1 ◦ . . . ◦ hin (Q), where hij = Gu,k ◦ Gs,k for some (u, s) ∈ G. By construction, X ⊂ {z ∈ J(f ) : z has itinerary in Σ′k and the forward orbit of z under f is bounded} and f 2p (X) = X. To prove Proposition 10, we will show that (7) dimH (X) > 1. By Bowen's formula (see e.g. [6, 12]), the Hausdorff dimension of X is determined as the unique t ∈ R, such that P (t) = 0 where P (t) is the pressure function: X 1 k(hi1 ◦ . . . ◦ hin )′ kt . Now we prove (8). By Lemma 1, for every z ∈ Hs , s ∈ Z and j = 1, . . . , p − 1, we have (9) |gkj (z)| ≤ |Re(gkj (z))| + |Im(gkj (z))| < ln |z| − ln |λ| + (2|s| + 1)π + | Arg(λ)| < ln |z| + 2π|s| + c3 for some constant c3 > 0. By (12) and the Koebe Lemma, the distortion of Gu,k is uniformly bounded on every vertical segment of endpoints vs , vs+1 , so X |G′u,k (vs )| (13) R − 2 ≤ length(l′u ) < c6 s: Gu,k (vs )∈l′u √ √ for some constant c6 > 0. Moreover, diam Q = 2R and (Gu,k ◦ Gs,k )′ (z) < 1/( 2R) for z ∈ Q (the proof is analogous to the proof of Lemma 8), so diam Qu,s < 1. Hence, if Gu,k (vs ) ∈ l′u ⊂ Q′ , then Qu,s ⊂ Q, so (u, s) ∈ G. Using (13), we conclude that X X X c5 |G′u,k (vs )| ≥ |G′u,k (vs )| > R(R − 2). c6 ′ ′ ′ (u,s)∈G u: lu ⊂Q s: Gu,k (vs )∈lu Combining this with (10), we get X X c5 R−2 , |G′u,k (vs )||G′s,k (zR )| > √ |(Gu,k ◦ Gs,k )′ (zR )| = (ln R + c4 )p−1 2c 6 (u,s)∈G (u,s)∈G which shows (8) for sufficiently large R. This completes the proof.  Note that it follows from the above proof that the set X ∪ f p (X) is a conformal f p invariant Cantor set and |(f p )′ | > 1 on X ∪ f p (X). Hence we immediately obtain the following. Proposition 11. The hyperbolic dimension of the set {z ∈ J(f ) : z has itinerary in Σ′k and the forward orbit of z under f is bounded} is greater than 1.  12 KRZYSZTOF BARAŃSKI, BOGUSLAWA KARPIŃSKA, AND ANNA ZDUNIK 5. Conclusion By Propositions 3, 4 and 10, the set ∂U0 ∩ I(f ) has Hausdorff dimension 1, while ∂U0 ∩ Jbd (f ) has Hausdorff dimension greater than 1. This implies 1 < dimH (∂U0 ∩ Jbd (f )) ≤ dimH (∂U0 \ I(f )) = dimH (∂U0 ). Of course, the same holds for any component U of the entire basin of attraction. This proves the first part of Theorem A, the lower estimate of the first part and the second part of Theorem B. The remaining part is a consequence of the second part of Theorem B and the fact dimH (J(f ) \ I(f )) < 2, which was proved in [15] as Theorem 6.1. Finally, the remark after Theorem B follows from Propositions 3 and 11. References [1] J. M. Aarts and L. G. Oversteegen, The geometry of Julia sets, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 338 (1993), 897-918.
